listings.bat_description: This 1999 Porsche 911 Carrera coupe is finished in Glacier White over a Graphite Grey interior with heated, fully power-adjustable, all-leather seats. It is powered by a 3.4-liter M96 flat-six paired with a six-speed manual transaxle, and it was also ordered with metal and aluminum-look cabin accents, a 220-series CD radio, a Hi-Fi sound system, and 18″ Turbo-look wheels. The seller purchased the car in August 2021, and subsequent work has included fitting an LN Engineering IMS Solution kit as well as replacing the clutch, flywheel, air oil separator, and spark plugs. This 996.1 coupe has 85k miles and is now offered at no reserve with the owner’s manual, service records, a clean Carfax report, and a clean Oregon title in the seller’s name.The car is finished in Glacier White (L3AU) and features an electric sunroof, integrated fog lights, a deployable rear spoiler, and dual exhaust outlets with polished finishers. Features include a blue soft top, an artic silver metallic removable hardtop, the Power Seat Package, xenon headlights, a deployable rear spoiler, 18″ Turbo-look wheels, cruise control, automatic climate control, and aluminum trim inlays on the shifter and parking brake lever. The car has 36k miles following history in New York, New Jersey, and Pennsylvania. This 996.1 cabriolet is now offered by the selling dealer with a clean Pennsylvania title.The car is finished in Arctic Silver Metallic (92U) and features a color-matched removable hardtop and a blue convertible soft top as well as xenon headlights, integrated fog lights, a deployable rear spoiler, and dual exhaust outlets with polished finishers. Highlights include the Miami Blue paintwork, a front-axle lift system, a Bose surround-sound system, and a variety of Miami Blue, aluminum, and carbon-fiber trim accents for the black leather and Alcantara interior. The car is powered by a twin-turbocharged 3.8L flat-six linked with a seven-speed PDK dual-clutch automatic transaxle and a limited-slip differential, and additional details include center-lock wheels, carbon-ceramic brakes, rear-axle steering, dynamic LED headlights, and navigation. Features include a power-operated sunroof, aftermarket front and rear spoilers, and 16” five-spoke wheels as well as a power-adjustable driver’s seat, an Alpine stereo, and an aftermarket shift knob. Acquired by the selling dealer in 2025, this Carrera coupe shows 71k miles and is now offered in New Jersey with workshop manuals, a clean Carfax report, and a clean New York title.The car is finished in black and has been fitted with aftermarket front and rear spoilers. It also has a power-operated sunroof, replacement headlights, and heated power-adjustable side mirrors. Close-up photos of exterior imperfections are shown in the gallery below.The 16” five-spoke wheels are mounted with 205/55 front and 225/50 rear Ohtsu tires. listings.bat_location: interior, su
listings.bat_description: Sep 11 at 4:26 PMAdoderoThis author's likes:189There are a few spots on the car that I’d call corrosion a potential concern or need more investigation. I am not an expert in these cars, but I’ve seen enough on those I’ve owned and others to know where to look. It’s a safe rule that, despite being galvanized, these cars are all rusting if you know where to look. All of them. The only real rust free examples are cars that have been disassembled in a quest to locate and eliminate corrosion, the rest will have it in some places, yes even if it’s a CA car. It’s even harder because Porsche adhesives look exactly like rust, so it’s hard to differentiate in photos.Some of this is due to age, a lot is due to design flaws and the lack of plastic shielding around the wheel wells that most modern cars have. They fling dirt, debris, and moisture up into bad places where it sits and corrodes over time. You will be hard pressed to find any 911 of this era or earlier that isn’t rusting somewhere, you
